utterances: Those short videos of funky dancing or fuzzy kittens on pianos passed by e-mail from inbox to inbox and for the most part left the mainstream media struggling to keep up.
But the video publishing revolution may be over as the world of online video changes from amateur hour.
SOUNDBITE OF AMATEUR ONLINE SUBMISSION
Okay.
Here we are, the world best card trick.
Spread the cards out and take a card or any card.
To just another tool for the pro's

Previously on Grey's Anatomy.
(As Dr. Miranda Bailey): What's going to happen to them?
Mr. JAMES PICKENS Jr. (Actor): (As Dr. Richard Webber) What?

PICKENS Jr.: (As Dr. Webber) Dr. Bailey, legally and technically, they have done nothing wrong.

In yesterday's San Jose Mercury News, Scott Kirsner argued that viewers on the net want less of Ask a Ninja and more of David Letterman.
The online video pendulum, he says, is swinging from corky home videos back to professional grade network TV quality.
So is it true, when you watch video online, do you want the often fuzzy but sometimes hilarious clips posted by part time moviemakers, or it is time to let the big kids into the online playground?
Would you rather see the networks in the studios post high-quality clips and made for TV shows?
Telling us what you're watching online and why.
E-mail is talk@npr.org.
Scott Kirsner wrote the book, ""The Future of Web Video."" He's the editor of the CinemaTech blog, and joins us now from the studios of member station WBUR in Boston.
Nice to have you in the program today.
It's great to be here, Neal.
So you say this is the beginning of the end for the populist revolution in online video?
You know, I do think that is, and the pendulum swing is exactly the term that I like to use.
If you look at a lot of media, when they first started out it was really the amateurs that glommed onto it and really understood what the potential was.
I kind of liken it to the early days of cinema, when you had people making these sort of aimless, pointless, very short movies, you know.
One of the first movies ever shown to a paying audience was ""Workers Leaving the Lumiere Factory"" in France, you know, literally people walking out of a factory.
Another one was a gardener getting sprayed with his own hose.
And I think if you'll look at YouTube now you see a lot of that same kind of stuff, you know, experimentation.

I actually did a little search on hose and sprayed on YouTube, and you get 50 videos of, you know, often it's a little kid in the backyard with the hose spraying his parents or spraying the family dog.
And I just love that parallel to the early days of cinema.
And obviously we know that movies evolved past the point of hose spraying, or maybe not if you've seen the Jackass movies recently.
Well, that's another issue, but nevertheless.
So you say this is, you know, sort of a function of media in general.
That every time a new medium comes up, you have what you call tech populous saying this is finally going to free us from the dominion of the big studios.
Exactly.

I mean, you know, people in Silicon Valley, where I am living right now, love the idea that a new technology comes along or new media comes along and it's going to remake the whole competitive landscape.
And suddenly amateurs are going to be on top and the professionals are going to be racing to catch up or stuck on the bottom of the pile.

And we saw it really just two years ago with podcasting where suddenly the technology became available to record an audio show in your kitchen and put it up on the Internet and allow anyone to listen to it.
And people said, suddenly, you know, someone from Kansas is going to be the next, you know, the next Howard Stern or the next Neal Conan.
And now, two years later, if you look at the list of the most popular podcasts, you'll see a lot of familiar names in it.
It's HBO and ESPN and the investing guru Jim Kramer.
And I should mention NPR too is now on the list of, you know, top 10, top 15 most popular podcasts.
So you suggest that new users, not necessarily those early users, but new users, as this starts to snowball, come on and they tend to look for brands that they're familiar with?
Yeah.
I do think that's true.
I mean there haven't been a lot of familiar brands on the Internet - in the world of Internet video over the last year.
I mean it has been a lot of amateur content.
And now as you see CBS putting up a lot of their shows, and they'll put up segments of the ""Late Show with David Letterman,"" or ABC will put up ""Desperate Housewives"" or ""Lost"".
Appreciate your time.

And before we let you go, Scott Kirsner, you tend to be arguing - and it seems to me you're arguing that this is a function of all new media and a function of - that this pendulum you're talking about is sort of a social law of sorts.
Conservation scientist Claudia Stickler of the University of Florida calls this international influence over the Amazon, teleconnections.
China and the E.U.
and a number of other emerging industrializing countries have basically adopted Brazil as their bread basket.
They don't have the capacity for a number of reasons to produce that kind of volume of food on their own, and so they're looking to countries like Brazil to do it for them.
Conservation scientists say to protect the climate, Brazil must protect the Amazon from these teleconnections.

Here in Mato Grosso, Dan Nepstad of the Woods Hole Research Center in Massachusetts visits forests owned by soy growers and advises them to cut less by getting more out of land that's already been cleared.
But he agrees that the world economy has numerous tentacles.
Take the ethanol-fuel boom in the U.S.
that's driving up the price of North American corn.
The price of corn affects this forest right here.
Because as we put a premium on ethanol, what we're doing is driving up the price for corn, displacing soybean in the United States.
And that translates into changes in the way farmers in South America think.
As North American farmers plant less soy, South American farmers clear more of the Amazon to fill the demand.
We're moving into a world where there's growing demand for that land in the Earth's surface that can be mechanically cultivated, that can be plowed and put into crops.
Brazil has had some success lately reducing the rate of deforestation.
Brazilian officials say they've locked up a lot of illegal loggers and land grabbers who burn land.
But conservationists say the demands and requirements of consumers worldwide are what may determine the fate of the Amazon's forests.
Christopher Joyce, NPR News.
And you can see a photo essay on Amazon Forest and get the latest Climate Connection stories from National Geographic magazine at our Web site, npr.org.
The Bush administration often accuses Iran of meddling in Iraq and supporting Shiite extremists.
But it has yet to offer any solid proof.
The State Department had promised to make its case against Iran public.
But it's holding off amid questions about just how solid U.S.
intelligence is.
NPR's Michele Keleman reports.
State Department spokesman John McCormick has said that the U.S.
has, as he put it, a mountain of evidence, convincing clear proof that Iranians are supplying Shiite groups in Iraq with weapons technology to kill U.S.
troops.
Last week he was promising to make it public.

There was apparently a challenge put out there, I believe, from the Iranian ambassador that night and said well, show us the evidence, show us the evidence that Iranian agents are engaged in these activities.
And Ambassador Khalilzad, rightly so, said we will present that evidence.
We will make it public.
McCormick said the U.S.
just wants to do it in a way that won't hurt its sources of information.
But today in Baghdad, U.S.
officials called off a briefing on the issue and officials in Washington are now downplaying expectations.
Georgetown professor Paul Pillar, a former national intelligence officer, is not surprised.

Certainly in the wake of the unhappy experiences with the evidence relating to Iraq and its supposed weapons of mass destruction, it should not be surprising that extra caution is being observed in not putting out anything publicly that might later be revealed to have been based on bad sources.
Beyond that, we can only speculate as to how much actually is there.
Iranian-made ordinance found in Iraq, he says, is not proof of Iranian government involvement, and he says it would be very difficult to trace attacks on U.S.
forces back to Iran, a thought echoed by retired Colonel Sam Gardiner.
Most Americans are killed in Sunni areas, not in the Shiite areas, so that you ask the question to what extent is the arming of the militia having a direct impact on Americans.
It certainly is to some degree.
But then to a larger degree, we don't know.
Gardiner says the Bush administration is trying to hype Iran's role in Iraq to elicit outrage among Americans.
Take for instance a recent case in Karbala, when attackers posing as Americans killed five U.S.
soldiers.
The Pentagon is investigating and U.S.
officials leaked word of possible Iranian involvement.
Many experts saw this as part of the U.S.
drumbeat against Iran.
And Paul Pillar is among those with serious questions about the reports.
Most of what we've heard pertaining to Iran is simply speculation to the effect that an operation this sophisticated must have had a government behind it.
I would caution against jumping toward that kind of conclusion.
There is one thing that everyone seems to agree on, that Iran's influence in Iraq is widespread.
Colonel Larry Wilkerson was former Secretary of State Colin Powell's chief of staff.
Iran is more or less sitting in the catbird seat with regard to Iraq and its position in Iraq.
So it doesn't need to do anything untoward.
That's not to say it isn't doing it.
But he's not convinced the Bush administration can make a persuasive case.

Even if they are doing something far more nefarious than that, and they very well could be, I don't think we have the intelligence capability to ferret it out and prove it in a definitive sort of way.

His former boss, Colin Powell, was the one to present faulty intelligence to the United Nations on Iraq, so Wilkerson says he can see why there seems to be some angst in the State Department about how and when to present its case on Iran.
Michele Keleman, NPR News, Washington.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
